citation.article-title: Bacteroides tectum sp. nov. and characteristics of other non pigmented Bacteroides isolates from soft-tissue infections from cats and dogs.

p.s: Description of Bacteroides tectum sp. nov.
Bacteroides tectum (tec'tum. L. adj. from tego to cover, to conceal, referring to difficulty in species identification)
Cells are obligately anaerobic, nonsporeforming, nonmotile, gram-negative rods.
In cooked meat-carbohydrate broth and on sheep blood agar plates, the cells are 0.6 to 0.8 by 1.2 to 5.0 μm and are arranged singly, in pairs, and in short chains.
On sheep blood agar plates, surface colonies after 48 h are 2 to 3 mm in diameter, circular, entire, dome shaped, grayish, and opaque.
No pigment is detected after 14 days on sheep blood agar or laked blood agar, and ultraviolet fluorescence (at 365 nm) is not detected at any time up to 14 days.
After incubation at 37°C for 24 h in prereduced broth media, cultures show uniform turbidity with a small deposit.

After incubation for 5 days, the pH values in media containing a fermentable carbohydrate generally range as follows: 5.5 to 5.7 in all strains which weakly ferment carbohydrates and 6.5 to 6.8 in media containing sugars that are not fermented by all strains (Table 1).
All strains grow well in peptone-yeast extract-glucose broth containing 20% bile.
Strains in homology groups I and II weakly ferment glucose, glycogen, and starch, although strains in homology group 111 do not.
Homology group II organisms ferment salicin on all occasions.
None of the strains ferments arabinose, esculin, mannitol, rhamnose , ribose, or trehalose.
All strains liquefy gelatin within 14 days, but none digests meat, reduce nitrates, or produces indole or catalase.
The acids produced in cooked meat-glucose broth cultures are acetic, propionic, and succinic acids (average concentrations, 17.5, 7, and 8 μmol/ml of culture, respectively).
Small amounts of isobutyric, isovaleric, and phenylacetic acids are also detected (average concentrations, 1.3,4, and 2 μmol/ml, respectively).
All strains are susceptible to penicillin (2 U/ml), amoxicillin (2.5 μg/ml), erythromycin (3 μg/ml), doxycycline (6 μg/ml), carbenicillin (100 μg/ml), and chloramphenicol (12 μg/ml)
The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 48 mol%, and the G+C contents of the other strains range from 47 to 48 mol%.
The type strain is strain NCTC 11853 (= 160), which was isolated from a subcutaneous fight wound abscess from a cat.
Strains of this species have been isolated from subcutaneous fight wound abscesses from cats and dogs, from pyothoraxes of cats, and from mouths of normal cats.
The following phenotypic characteristics are helpful in differentiating B. tecrum from other species.

All strains of B. tecrum grow well in 20% bile; this differentiates them from Bacteroides capillosis (Table 4), which ferments a similar range of sugars and also hydrolyzes esculin. Bacteroides disiens, Bacteroides amylophilus, and Bacteroides corporis can also be differentiated phenotypically from B. tecrum (Table 4).
In addition, B. corporis produces dark brown colonies after 4 to 7 days.
